comment_text.mn21:2.1: This monk appears in three discourses, in none of which he distinguishes himself. At SN 12.12 he persistently attempts to rephrase questions on dependent origination in terms of a self. And at SN 12.32 Venerable Sāriputta gets word that Phagguna had disrobed. According to the commentary, he was called Phagguna “of the Top-Knot” because of the style he wore his hair as a layperson. The name stuck, presumably to distinguish him from the Phagguna of AN 6.56 (and probably SN 35.83) who died in robes as a non-returner after hearing a Dhamma talk.
comment_text.mn21:2.3: A “disciplinary proceeding” (adhikaraṇa) is a legal case in Vinaya. A standard set of four is listed at MN 104:12.3. The kind of case is not specified in the text, but the commentary says they accused other mendicants of various offences and got Vinaya experts to litigate them, making it a “disciplinary issue arising from accusations” (anuvādādhikaraṇa, Kd 14:14.2.7).
comment_text.mn21:6.6: This does not mean, of course, that one should not defend people against violence (see eg. DN 16:1.4.15), but that even in such circumstances one should not give way to anger.
comment_text.mn21:6.10: The grammar here is a little tricky. The genitive plays two roles in these passages: specifying the context (tava sammukhā, “in your presence”), and as the object of criticism or blows (pahāraṁ dadeyya “if they strike” operates above on “those nuns” (tāsaṁ bhikkhunīnaṁ) and below on “you” (tava)). Here we would expect both senses to be used, but the text only has tava once. I assume that either one instance of tava has been lost or it is meant to be distributed.
comment_text.mn21:6.13: Here sammukhā is omitted, as it is unnecessary to specify being hit in your own presence.
comment_text.mn21:7.4: Eating once a day is also encouraged at MN 65, while MN 70 encourages not eating at night. In both cases, monks objected when asked to follow this practice. Thus all three instances depict the growing influence of recalcitrant monks in the Sangha, culminating in the Buddha laying down a formal Vinaya rule against eating at the wrong time (Bu Pc 37). Per the allowance at MN 65:4.1, the mendicants are not required to eat in one sitting, which remained as an optional ascetic practice.
comment_text.mn21:7.9: This is referring to the early years of the dispensation, before the formal Vinaya code was laid down. The Buddha was reluctant to create a legal code and did so only when it became necessary (Bu Pj 1:3.4.6). He preferred to lead without judgment and punishment, but by reason, positive encouragement, and inspiring with his own example.
comment_text.mn21:7.10: This simile is also at MN 119:31.2, SN 35.239:2.10, and AN 5.28:10.2.
comment_text.mn21:9.1: The lady Vedehikā is known only here. According to the commentary, her name means either “daughter of the lady from Videha”, or (implausibly) “wise one”. However, the much earlier Arthaśāstra treats vaidehika either as a “merchant” (2.21.7) or as a caste name (3.7.32). This story paints a rare portrait of domestic life.
comment_text.mn21:9.3: The same set of three in a similar context occur at AN 6.60.
comment_text.mn21:9.4: According to ancient Indian law (Arthaśāstra 3.13), slaves may be born such, be captured in war, or a person in a time of trouble may bind themselves in service for a fee. Non-Aryans (mleccha) may indenture their children, but this is forbidden for Aryans. Such bondservants were protected against cruelty, sexual abuse, and unfair work. After earning back the fee of their indenture they were freed, retaining their original inheritance and status. | The maid’s name means “black” (compare the Kāḷī at Thag 2.16:1.1 who “looks like a crow”). This is a persistent pattern in early Pali. The only other named slaves are Disā (“foe”, DN 3:1.16.1), her son Kaṇha (“black”, DN 3:1.16.1), and Kāka (“crow”, Kd 8:1.26.6). These people were evidently non-Aryans descended from the native peoples of India, perhaps Tamils or other tribal groups.
comment_text.mn21:9.10: To “test” (or “inquire”) is vīmaṁsā, which features as the fourth of the bases of psychic power.
comment_text.mn21:9.13: He je is an idiomatic and disrespectful form of address, offering a glimpse of colloquial speech in the formal Pali of scripture. He is an exclamation for calling attention, like “hey” but cruder. Je is a derogatory term for women, used here and by the Vajjīs to Ambapālī at DN 16:2.16.3.
comment_text.mn21:9.14: She uses the respectful address ayye (“ma’am”).
comment_text.mn21:9.33: Assuming that the three rounds are meant to be divā, divātaraṁ, divātaraṁyeva (“in the day”, “later in the day”, “even later in the day”), although this is not followed consistently in the text.
comment_text.mn21:9.39: Aggaḷasūci is a “pin” (sūci) for fastening the “door” (aggala). It is sometimes translated as “rolling pin”, but that would be Sanskrit vellana (Hindi belan).
comment_text.mn21:9.43: Arthaśāstra 3.13.9 says that inflicting punishment (daṇḍapreṣaṇam; cf. Pali daṇḍāpesuṁ at Bi Ss 1:1.38) on a slave is a crime for which a master incurs a fine equivalent to the cost of the slave.
comment_text.mn21:9.45: No blame is given to Kāḷī for her deliberate provocation.
comment_text.mn21:11.1: At AN 5.167 and AN 10.44:7.1 the five positive ways should be established before admonishing anyone.
comment_text.mn21:11.14: Up until now, the sutta has concerned itself with good behavior and motivations in everyday life. Now this forms a basis to support meditation.
comment_text.mn21:14.8: “No form or appearance” is arūpī anidassano.
comment_text.mn21:20.1: This is often depicted as one of the torments of hell.
comment_text.mn21:21.1: This dramatic passage is quoted at MN 28:24.3, which adopts the name “The Advice on the Simile of the Saw” (kakacūpamovāda). It became one of the most famous similes in Buddhism. In addition to these two Majjhima suttas and their Chinese parallels, it is cited in canonical texts at Thag 6.12:5.2 and SA 497, and in commentarial texts such as the Sanskrit Abhidharma text Mahāvibhāṣā (T 1545 at T xxvii 190a28), the Pali commentary to Ud 3.3, and the Visuddhimagga chapter on loving-kindness meditation (Vsm 2.9.15). A similar sentiment, moreover, is expressed in the Jain Isibhāsiyāiṁ chapter 34.

root_text.mn21:1.2: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṁ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
root_text.mn21:2.1: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā moḷiyaphagguno bhikkhunīhi saddhiṁ ativelaṁ saṁsaṭṭho viharati.
root_text.mn21:2.2: Evaṁ saṁsaṭṭho āyasmā moḷiyaphagguno bhikkhunīhi saddhiṁ viharati—
root_text.mn21:2.3: sace koci bhikkhu āyasmato moḷiyaphaggunassa sammukhā tāsaṁ bhikkhunīnaṁ avaṇṇaṁ bhāsati, tenāyasmā moḷiyaphagguno kupito anattamano adhikaraṇampi karoti.
root_text.mn21:2.4: Sace pana koci bhikkhu tāsaṁ bhikkhunīnaṁ sammukhā āyasmato moḷiyaphaggunassa avaṇṇaṁ bhāsati, tena tā bhikkhuniyo kupitā anattamanā adhikaraṇampi karonti.
root_text.mn21:2.5: Evaṁ saṁsaṭṭho āyasmā moḷiyaphagguno bhikkhunīhi saddhiṁ viharati.
root_text.mn21:3.1: Atha kho aññataro bhikkhu yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho so bhikkhu bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn21:3.2: “āyasmā, bhante, moḷiyaphagguno bhikkhunīhi saddhiṁ ativelaṁ saṁsaṭṭho viharati.
root_text.mn21:3.3: Evaṁ saṁsaṭṭho, bhante, āyasmā moḷiyaphagguno bhikkhunīhi saddhiṁ viharati—
root_text.mn21:3.4: sace koci bhikkhu āyasmato moḷiyaphaggunassa sammukhā tāsaṁ bhikkhunīnaṁ avaṇṇaṁ bhāsati, tenāyasmā moḷiyaphagguno kupito anattamano adhikaraṇampi karoti.
root_text.mn21:3.5: Sace pana koci bhikkhu tāsaṁ bhikkhunīnaṁ sammukhā āyasmato moḷiyaphaggunassa avaṇṇaṁ bhāsati, tena tā bhikkhuniyo kupitā anattamanā adhikaraṇampi karonti.
root_text.mn21:3.6: Evaṁ saṁsaṭṭho, bhante, āyasmā moḷiyaphagguno bhikkhunīhi saddhiṁ viharatī”ti.
root_text.mn21:4.1: Atha kho bhagavā aññataraṁ bhikkhuṁ āmantesi:
root_text.mn21:4.2: “ehi tvaṁ, bhikkhu, mama vacanena moḷiyaphaggunaṁ bhikkhuṁ āmantehi:
root_text.mn21:4.4: “Evaṁ, bhante”ti kho so bhikkhu bhagavato paṭissutvā yenāyasmā moḷiyaphagguno tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṁ moḷiyaphaggunaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn21:4.6: “Evamāvuso”ti kho āyasmā moḷiyaphagguno tassa bhikkhuno paṭissutvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinnaṁ kho āyasmantaṁ moḷiyaphaggunaṁ bhagavā etadavoca:
root_text.mn21:5.1: “Saccaṁ kira tvaṁ, phagguna, bhikkhunīhi saddhiṁ ativelaṁ saṁsaṭṭho viharasi?
root_text.mn21:5.2: Evaṁ saṁsaṭṭho kira tvaṁ, phagguna, bhikkhunīhi saddhiṁ viharasi—
root_text.mn21:5.3: sace koci bhikkhu tuyhaṁ sammukhā tāsaṁ bhikkhunīnaṁ avaṇṇaṁ bhāsati, tena tvaṁ kupito anattamano adhikaraṇampi karosi.
root_text.mn21:5.4: Sace pana koci bhikkhu tāsaṁ bhikkhunīnaṁ sammukhā tuyhaṁ avaṇṇaṁ bhāsati, tena tā bhikkhuniyo kupitā anattamanā adhikaraṇampi karonti.
root_text.mn21:5.5: Evaṁ saṁsaṭṭho kira tvaṁ, phagguna, bhikkhunīhi saddhiṁ viharasī”ti?
root_text.mn21:5.7: “Nanu tvaṁ, phagguna, kulaputto saddhā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajito”ti?
root_text.mn21:6.1: “Na kho te etaṁ, phagguna, patirūpaṁ kulaputtassa saddhā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajitassa, yaṁ tvaṁ bhikkhunīhi saddhiṁ ativelaṁ saṁsaṭṭho vihareyyāsi.
root_text.mn21:6.2: Tasmātiha, phagguna, tava cepi koci sammukhā tāsaṁ bhikkhunīnaṁ avaṇṇaṁ bhāseyya, tatrāpi tvaṁ, phagguna, ye gehasitā chandā ye gehasitā vitakkā te pajaheyyāsi.
root_text.mn21:6.4: ‘na ceva me cittaṁ vipariṇataṁ bhavissati, na ca pāpikaṁ vācaṁ nicchāressāmi, hitānukampī ca viharissāmi mettacitto, na dosantaro’ti.
root_text.mn21:6.6: Tasmātiha, phagguna, tava cepi koci sammukhā tāsaṁ bhikkhunīnaṁ pāṇinā pahāraṁ dadeyya, leḍḍunā pahāraṁ dadeyya, daṇḍena pahāraṁ dadeyya, satthena pahāraṁ dadeyya. Tatrāpi tvaṁ, phagguna, ye gehasitā chandā ye gehasitā vitakkā te pajaheyyāsi.
root_text.mn21:6.8: ‘na ceva me cittaṁ vipariṇataṁ bhavissati, na ca pāpikaṁ vācaṁ nicchāressāmi, hitānukampī ca viharissāmi mettacitto, na dosantaro’ti.
root_text.mn21:6.10: Tasmātiha, phagguna, tava cepi koci sammukhā avaṇṇaṁ bhāseyya, tatrāpi tvaṁ, phagguna, ye gehasitā chandā ye gehasitā vitakkā te pajaheyyāsi.
root_text.mn21:6.11: Tatrāpi te, phagguna, evaṁ sikkhitabbaṁ ‘na ceva me cittaṁ vipariṇataṁ bhavissati, na ca pāpikaṁ vācaṁ nicchāressāmi, hitānukampī ca viharissāmi mettacitto, na dosantaro’ti.
root_text.mn21:6.13: Tasmātiha, phagguna, tava cepi koci pāṇinā pahāraṁ dadeyya, leḍḍunā pahāraṁ dadeyya, daṇḍena pahāraṁ dadeyya, satthena pahāraṁ dadeyya, tatrāpi tvaṁ, phagguna, ye gehasitā chandā ye gehasitā vitakkā te pajaheyyāsi.
root_text.mn21:6.14: Tatrāpi te, phagguna, evaṁ sikkhitabbaṁ ‘na ceva me cittaṁ vipariṇataṁ bhavissati, na ca pāpikaṁ vācaṁ nicchāressāmi, hitānukampī ca viharissāmi mettacitto, na dosantaro’ti.
root_text.mn21:7.2: “ārādhayiṁsu vata me, bhikkhave, bhikkhū ekaṁ samayaṁ cittaṁ.
root_text.mn21:7.5: Ekāsanabhojanaṁ kho ahaṁ, bhikkhave, bhuñjamāno appābādhatañca sañjānāmi appātaṅkatañca lahuṭṭhānañca balañca phāsuvihārañca.
root_text.mn21:7.7: Ekāsanabhojanaṁ kho, bhikkhave, tumhepi bhuñjamānā appābādhatañca sañjānissatha appātaṅkatañca lahuṭṭhānañca balañca phāsuvihārañcāti.
root_text.mn21:7.8: Na me, bhikkhave, tesu bhikkhūsu anusāsanī karaṇīyā ahosi;
root_text.mn21:7.9: satuppādakaraṇīyameva me, bhikkhave, tesu bhikkhūsu ahosi.
root_text.mn21:7.10: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, subhūmiyaṁ catumahāpathe ājaññaratho yutto assa ṭhito odhastapatodo.
root_text.mn21:7.11: Tamenaṁ dakkho yoggācariyo assadammasārathi abhiruhitvā, vāmena hatthena rasmiyo gahetvā, dakkhiṇena hatthena patodaṁ gahetvā, yenicchakaṁ yadicchakaṁ sāreyyapi paccāsāreyyapi.
root_text.mn21:7.12: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, na me tesu bhikkhūsu anusāsanī karaṇīyā ahosi,
root_text.mn21:7.13: satuppādakaraṇīyameva me, bhikkhave, tesu bhikkhūsu ahosi.
root_text.mn21:7.14: Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, tumhepi akusalaṁ pajahatha, kusalesu dhammesu āyogaṁ karotha.
root_text.mn21:7.15: Evañhi tumhepi imasmiṁ dhammavinaye vuddhiṁ virūḷhiṁ vepullaṁ āpajjissatha.
root_text.mn21:8.1: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, gāmassa vā nigamassa vā avidūre mahantaṁ sālavanaṁ.
root_text.mn21:8.3: Tassa kocideva puriso uppajjeyya atthakāmo hitakāmo yogakkhemakāmo.
root_text.mn21:8.4: So yā tā sālalaṭṭhiyo kuṭilā ojāpaharaṇiyo tā chetvā bahiddhā nīhareyya, antovanaṁ suvisodhitaṁ visodheyya.
root_text.mn21:8.5: Yā pana tā sālalaṭṭhiyo ujukā sujātā tā sammā parihareyya.
root_text.mn21:8.6: Evañhetaṁ, bhikkhave, sālavanaṁ aparena samayena vuddhiṁ virūḷhiṁ vepullaṁ āpajjeyya.
root_text.mn21:8.7: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, tumhepi akusalaṁ pajahatha, kusalesu dhammesu āyogaṁ karotha.
root_text.mn21:8.8: Evañhi tumhepi imasmiṁ dhammavinaye vuddhiṁ virūḷhiṁ vepullaṁ āpajjissatha.
root_text.mn21:9.1: Bhūtapubbaṁ, bhikkhave, imissāyeva sāvatthiyā vedehikā nāma gahapatānī ahosi.
root_text.mn21:9.2: Vedehikāya, bhikkhave, gahapatāniyā evaṁ kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggato:
root_text.mn21:9.3: ‘soratā vedehikā gahapatānī, nivātā vedehikā gahapatānī, upasantā vedehikā gahapatānī’ti.
root_text.mn21:9.4: Vedehikāya kho pana, bhikkhave, gahapatāniyā kāḷī nāma dāsī ahosi dakkhā analasā susaṁvihitakammantā.
root_text.mn21:9.5: Atha kho, bhikkhave, kāḷiyā dāsiyā etadahosi:
root_text.mn21:9.6: ‘mayhaṁ kho ayyāya evaṁ kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggato:
root_text.mn21:9.7: “soratā vedehikā gahapatānī, nivātā vedehikā gahapatānī, upasantā vedehikā gahapatānī”ti.
root_text.mn21:9.8: Kiṁ nu kho me ayyā santaṁyeva nu kho ajjhattaṁ kopaṁ na pātukaroti udāhu asantaṁ
root_text.mn21:9.9: udāhu mayhamevete kammantā susaṁvihitā yena me ayyā santaṁyeva ajjhattaṁ kopaṁ na pātukaroti, no asantaṁ?
root_text.mn21:9.11: Atha kho, bhikkhave, kāḷī dāsī divā uṭṭhāsi.
root_text.mn21:9.12: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vedehikā gahapatānī kāḷiṁ dāsiṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn21:9.17: ‘No vata re kiñci, pāpi dāsi, divā uṭṭhāsī’ti kupitā anattamanā bhākuṭiṁ akāsi.
root_text.mn21:9.18: Atha kho, bhikkhave, kāḷiyā dāsiyā etadahosi:
root_text.mn21:9.19: ‘santaṁyeva kho me ayyā ajjhattaṁ kopaṁ na pātukaroti, no asantaṁ;
root_text.mn21:9.20: mayhamevete kammantā susaṁvihitā, yena me ayyā santaṁyeva ajjhattaṁ kopaṁ na pātukaroti, no asantaṁ.
root_text.mn21:9.22: Atha kho, bhikkhave, kāḷī dāsī divātaraṁyeva uṭṭhāsi.
root_text.mn21:9.23: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vedehikā gahapatānī kāḷiṁ dāsiṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn21:9.28: ‘No vata re kiñci, pāpi dāsi, divātaraṁ uṭṭhāsī’ti kupitā anattamanā anattamanavācaṁ nicchāresi.
root_text.mn21:9.29: Atha kho, bhikkhave, kāḷiyā dāsiyā etadahosi:
root_text.mn21:9.30: ‘santaṁyeva kho me ayyā ajjhattaṁ kopaṁ na pātukaroti, no asantaṁ.
root_text.mn21:9.31: Mayhamevete kammantā susaṁvihitā, yena me ayyā santaṁyeva ajjhattaṁ kopaṁ na pātukaroti, no asantaṁ.
root_text.mn21:9.33: Atha kho, bhikkhave, kāḷī dāsī divātaraṁyeva uṭṭhāsi.
root_text.mn21:9.34: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vedehikā gahapatānī kāḷiṁ dāsiṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn21:9.39: ‘No vata re kiñci, pāpi dāsi, divā uṭṭhāsī’ti kupitā anattamanā aggaḷasūciṁ gahetvā sīse pahāraṁ adāsi, sīsaṁ vobhindi.
root_text.mn21:9.40: Atha kho, bhikkhave, kāḷī dāsī bhinnena sīsena lohitena galantena paṭivissakānaṁ ujjhāpesi:
root_text.mn21:9.42: passathayye, nivātāya kammaṁ, passathayye, upasantāya kammaṁ.
root_text.mn21:9.43: Kathañhi nāma ekadāsikāya divā uṭṭhāsīti kupitā anattamanā aggaḷasūciṁ gahetvā sīse pahāraṁ dassati, sīsaṁ vobhindissatī’ti.
root_text.mn21:9.44: Atha kho, bhikkhave, vedehikāya gahapatāniyā aparena samayena evaṁ pāpako kittisaddo abbhuggacchi:
root_text.mn21:9.45: ‘caṇḍī vedehikā gahapatānī, anivātā vedehikā gahapatānī, anupasantā vedehikā gahapatānī’ti.
root_text.mn21:10.1: Evameva kho, bhikkhave, idhekacco bhikkhu tāvadeva soratasorato hoti nivātanivāto hoti upasantūpasanto hoti yāva na amanāpā vacanapathā phusanti.
root_text.mn21:10.2: Yato ca, bhikkhave, bhikkhuṁ amanāpā vacanapathā phusanti, atha bhikkhu ‘sorato’ti veditabbo, ‘nivāto’ti veditabbo, ‘upasanto’ti veditabbo.
root_text.mn21:10.3: Nāhaṁ taṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhuṁ ‘suvaco’ti vadāmi yo cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhārahetu suvaco hoti, sovacassataṁ āpajjati.
root_text.mn21:10.5: Tañhi so, bhikkhave, bhikkhu cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhāraṁ alabhamāno na suvaco hoti, na sovacassataṁ āpajjati.
root_text.mn21:10.6: Yo ca kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dhammaṁyeva sakkaronto, dhammaṁ garuṁ karonto, dhammaṁ mānento, dhammaṁ pūjento, dhammaṁ apacāyamāno suvaco hoti, sovacassataṁ āpajjati, tamahaṁ ‘suvaco’ti vadāmi.
root_text.mn21:10.7: Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, ‘dhammaṁyeva sakkarontā, dhammaṁ garuṁ karontā, dhammaṁ mānentā, dhammaṁ pūjentā, dhammaṁ apacāyamānā suvacā bhavissāma, sovacassataṁ āpajjissāmā’ti.
root_text.mn21:11.1: Pañcime, bhikkhave, vacanapathā yehi vo pare vadamānā vadeyyuṁ—
root_text.mn21:11.7: Kālena vā, bhikkhave, pare vadamānā vadeyyuṁ akālena vā;
root_text.mn21:11.8: bhūtena vā, bhikkhave, pare vadamānā vadeyyuṁ abhūtena vā;
root_text.mn21:11.9: saṇhena vā, bhikkhave, pare vadamānā vadeyyuṁ pharusena vā;
root_text.mn21:11.10: atthasaṁhitena vā, bhikkhave, pare vadamānā vadeyyuṁ anatthasaṁhitena vā;
root_text.mn21:11.11: mettacittā vā, bhikkhave, pare vadamānā vadeyyuṁ dosantarā vā.
root_text.mn21:11.13: ‘na ceva no cittaṁ vipariṇataṁ bhavissati, na ca pāpikaṁ vācaṁ nicchāressāma, hitānukampī ca viharissāma mettacittā, na dosantarā.
root_text.mn21:11.14: Tañca puggalaṁ mettāsahagatena cetasā pharitvā viharissāma, tadārammaṇañca sabbāvantaṁ lokaṁ mettāsahagatena cittena vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena abyābajjhena pharitvā viharissāmā’ti.
root_text.mn21:12.1: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, puriso āgaccheyya kudālapiṭakaṁ ādāya.
root_text.mn21:12.4: So tatra tatra vikhaṇeyya, tatra tatra vikireyya, tatra tatra oṭṭhubheyya, tatra tatra omutteyya:
root_text.mn21:12.7: api nu so puriso imaṁ mahāpathaviṁ apathaviṁ kareyyā”ti?
root_text.mn21:12.12: yāvadeva ca pana so puriso kilamathassa vighātassa bhāgī assā”ti.
root_text.mn21:13.1: “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, pañcime vacanapathā yehi vo pare vadamānā vadeyyuṁ—
root_text.mn21:13.7: Kālena vā, bhikkhave, pare vadamānā vadeyyuṁ akālena vā;
root_text.mn21:13.8: bhūtena vā bhikkhave, pare vadamānā vadeyyuṁ abhūtena vā;
root_text.mn21:13.9: saṇhena vā, bhikkhave, pare vadamānā vadeyyuṁ pharusena vā;
root_text.mn21:13.10: atthasaṁhitena vā, bhikkhave, pare vadamānā vadeyyuṁ anatthasaṁhitena vā;
root_text.mn21:13.11: mettacittā vā, bhikkhave, pare vadamānā vadeyyuṁ dosantarā vā.
root_text.mn21:13.13: ‘na ceva no cittaṁ vipariṇataṁ bhavissati, na ca pāpikaṁ vācaṁ nicchāressāma, hitānukampī ca viharissāma mettacittā na dosantarā.
root_text.mn21:13.14: Tañca puggalaṁ mettāsahagatena cetasā pharitvā viharissāma, tadārammaṇañca sabbāvantaṁ lokaṁ pathavisamena cetasā vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena abyābajjhena pharitvā viharissāmā’ti.
root_text.mn21:14.1: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, puriso āgaccheyya lākhaṁ vā haliddiṁ vā nīlaṁ vā mañjiṭṭhaṁ vā ādāya.
root_text.mn21:14.3: ‘ahaṁ imasmiṁ ākāse rūpaṁ likhissāmi, rūpapātubhāvaṁ karissāmī’ti.
root_text.mn21:14.5: api nu so puriso imasmiṁ ākāse rūpaṁ likheyya, rūpapātubhāvaṁ kareyyā”ti?
root_text.mn21:14.9: Tattha na sukaraṁ rūpaṁ likhituṁ, rūpapātubhāvaṁ kātuṁ;
root_text.mn21:14.10: yāvadeva ca pana so puriso kilamathassa vighātassa bhāgī assā”ti.
root_text.mn21:15.1: “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, pañcime vacanapathā yehi vo pare vadamānā vadeyyuṁ kālena vā akālena vā …pe…
root_text.mn21:15.2: tadārammaṇañca sabbāvantaṁ lokaṁ ākāsasamena cetasā vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena abyābajjhena pharitvā viharissāmā’ti.
root_text.mn21:16.1: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, puriso āgaccheyya ādittaṁ tiṇukkaṁ ādāya.
root_text.mn21:16.3: ‘ahaṁ imāya ādittāya tiṇukkāya gaṅgaṁ nadiṁ santāpessāmi samparitāpessāmī’ti.
root_text.mn21:16.5: api nu so puriso ādittāya tiṇukkāya gaṅgaṁ nadiṁ santāpeyya samparitāpeyyā”ti?
root_text.mn21:16.9: Sā na sukarā ādittāya tiṇukkāya santāpetuṁ samparitāpetuṁ;
root_text.mn21:16.10: yāvadeva ca pana so puriso kilamathassa vighātassa bhāgī assā”ti.
root_text.mn21:17.1: “Evameva kho, bhikkhave, pañcime vacanapathā yehi vo pare vadamānā vadeyyuṁ kālena vā akālena vā …pe…
root_text.mn21:17.2: tadārammaṇañca sabbāvantaṁ lokaṁ gaṅgāsamena cetasā vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena abyābajjhena pharitvā viharissāmā’ti.
root_text.mn21:18.1: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, biḷārabhastā madditā sumadditā suparimadditā, mudukā tūlinī chinnasassarā chinnabhabbharā.
root_text.mn21:18.2: Atha puriso āgaccheyya kaṭṭhaṁ vā kathalaṁ vā ādāya.
root_text.mn21:18.4: ‘ahaṁ imaṁ biḷārabhastaṁ madditaṁ sumadditaṁ suparimadditaṁ, mudukaṁ tūliniṁ, chinnasassaraṁ chinnabhabbharaṁ kaṭṭhena vā kathalena vā sarasaraṁ karissāmi bharabharaṁ karissāmī’ti.
root_text.mn21:18.6: api nu so puriso amuṁ biḷārabhastaṁ madditaṁ sumadditaṁ suparimadditaṁ, mudukaṁ tūliniṁ, chinnasassaraṁ chinnabhabbharaṁ kaṭṭhena vā kathalena vā sarasaraṁ kareyya, bharabharaṁ kareyyā”ti?
root_text.mn21:18.9: “Amu hi, bhante, biḷārabhastā madditā sumadditā suparimadditā, mudukā tūlinī, chinnasassarā chinnabhabbharā.
root_text.mn21:18.10: Sā na sukarā kaṭṭhena vā kathalena vā sarasaraṁ kātuṁ bharabharaṁ kātuṁ;
root_text.mn21:18.11: yāvadeva ca pana so puriso kilamathassa vighātassa bhāgī assā”ti.

root_text.mn21:19.8: bhūtena vā, bhikkhave, pare vadamānā vadeyyuṁ abhūtena vā;

root_text.mn21:20.1: Ubhatodaṇḍakena cepi, bhikkhave, kakacena corā ocarakā aṅgamaṅgāni okanteyyuṁ, tatrāpi yo mano padūseyya, na me so tena sāsanakaro.
root_text.mn21:20.3: ‘na ceva no cittaṁ vipariṇataṁ bhavissati, na ca pāpikaṁ vācaṁ nicchāressāma, hitānukampī ca viharissāma mettacittā na dosantarā.
root_text.mn21:20.4: Tañca puggalaṁ mettāsahagatena cetasā pharitvā viharissāma tadārammaṇañca sabbāvantaṁ lokaṁ mettāsahagatena cetasā vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena abyābajjhena pharitvā viharissāmā’ti.
root_text.mn21:21.1: Imañca tumhe, bhikkhave, kakacūpamaṁ ovādaṁ abhikkhaṇaṁ manasi kareyyātha.
root_text.mn21:21.2: Passatha no tumhe, bhikkhave, taṁ vacanapathaṁ, aṇuṁ vā thūlaṁ vā, yaṁ tumhe nādhivāseyyāthā”ti?
root_text.mn21:21.4: “Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, imaṁ kakacūpamaṁ ovādaṁ abhikkhaṇaṁ manasikarotha.
root_text.mn21:21.5: Taṁ vo bhavissati dīgharattaṁ hitāya sukhāyā”ti.
root_text.mn21:21.7: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandunti.

translation_text.mn21:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
translation_text.mn21:2.1: Now at that time, Venerable Phagguna of the Top-Knot was spending too long mixing closely with some nuns.
translation_text.mn21:2.3: if any mendicant criticized those nuns in his presence, Phagguna of the Top-Knot got angry and upset, and even instigated disciplinary proceedings.
translation_text.mn21:2.4: And if any mendicant criticized Phagguna of the Top-Knot in their presence, those nuns got angry and upset, and even instigated disciplinary proceedings.
translation_text.mn21:2.5: That’s how close Phagguna of the Top-Knot was with those nuns.
translation_text.mn21:3.1: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what was going on.
translation_text.mn21:4.1: So the Buddha addressed one of the monks,
translation_text.mn21:4.2: “Please, monk, in my name tell the mendicant Phagguna of the Top-Knot that
translation_text.mn21:4.4: “Yes, sir,” that monk replied. He went to Phagguna of the Top-Knot and said to him,
translation_text.mn21:4.6: “Yes, reverend,” Phagguna replied. He went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him:
translation_text.mn21:5.1: “Is it really true, Phagguna, that you’ve been spending too long mixing closely with some nuns?
translation_text.mn21:5.3: if any mendicant criticizes those nuns in your presence, you get angry and upset, and even instigate disciplinary proceedings?
translation_text.mn21:5.4: And if any mendicant criticizes you in those nuns’ presence, they get angry and upset, and even instigate disciplinary proceedings?
translation_text.mn21:5.5: Is that how close you’ve become with those nuns?”
translation_text.mn21:5.7: “Phagguna, are you not a gentleman who has gone forth out of faith from the lay life to homelessness?”
translation_text.mn21:6.1: “As such, it’s not appropriate for you to mix so closely with those nuns.
translation_text.mn21:6.2: So if anyone criticizes those nuns in your presence, you should give up any desires or thoughts of domestic life.
translation_text.mn21:6.3: If that happens, you should train like this:
translation_text.mn21:6.4: ‘My mind will not degenerate. I will blurt out no bad words. I will remain full of sympathy, with a heart of love and no secret hate.’
translation_text.mn21:6.6: So even if someone strikes those nuns with fists, stones, rods, and swords in your presence, you should give up any desires or thoughts of domestic life.
translation_text.mn21:6.7: If that happens, you should train like this:
translation_text.mn21:6.8: ‘My mind will not degenerate. I will blurt out no bad words. I will remain full of sympathy, with a heart of love and no secret hate.’
translation_text.mn21:6.10: So if anyone criticizes you in your presence, you should give up any desires or thoughts of domestic life.
translation_text.mn21:6.11: If that happens, you should train like this: ‘My mind will not degenerate. I will blurt out no bad words. I will remain full of sympathy, with a heart of love and no secret hate.’
translation_text.mn21:6.13: So Phagguna, even if someone strikes you with fists, stones, rods, and swords, you should give up any desires or thoughts of domestic life.
translation_text.mn21:6.14: If that happens, you should train like this: ‘My mind will not degenerate. I will blurt out no bad words. I will remain full of sympathy, with a heart of love and no secret hate.’
translation_text.mn21:7.1: Then the Buddha said to the mendicants:
translation_text.mn21:7.2: “Mendicants, I used to be satisfied with the mendicants.
translation_text.mn21:7.4: ‘I eat my food in one sitting per day.
translation_text.mn21:7.5: Doing so, I find that I’m healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably.
translation_text.mn21:7.6: You too should eat your food in one sitting per day.
translation_text.mn21:7.7: Doing so, you’ll find that you’re healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably.’
translation_text.mn21:7.8: I didn’t have to keep on instructing those mendicants;
translation_text.mn21:7.9: I just had to prompt their mindfulness.
translation_text.mn21:7.10: Suppose a chariot stood harnessed to thoroughbreds at a level crossroads, with a goad ready.
translation_text.mn21:7.11: A deft horse trainer, a master charioteer, might mount the chariot, taking the reins in his right hand and goad in the left. He’d drive out and back wherever he wishes, whenever he wishes.
translation_text.mn21:7.12: In the same way, I didn’t have to keep on instructing those mendicants;
translation_text.mn21:7.13: I just had to prompt their mindfulness.
translation_text.mn21:7.14: So, mendicants, you too should give up what’s unskillful and devote yourselves to skillful qualities.
translation_text.mn21:7.15: In this way you’ll achieve growth, improvement, and maturity in this teaching and training.
translation_text.mn21:8.1: Suppose that not far from a town or village there was a large grove of sal trees
translation_text.mn21:8.2: that was choked with castor-oil weeds.
translation_text.mn21:8.3: Then along comes a person who wants to help protect and nurture that grove.
translation_text.mn21:8.4: They’d cut down the crooked sal saplings that were robbing the sap, and throw them out. They’d clean up the interior of the grove,
translation_text.mn21:8.5: and properly care for the straight, well-formed sal saplings.
translation_text.mn21:8.6: In this way, in due course, that sal grove would grow, increase, and mature.
translation_text.mn21:8.7: In the same way, mendicants, you too should give up what’s unskillful and devote yourselves to skillful qualities.
translation_text.mn21:8.8: In this way you’ll achieve growth, improvement, and maturity in this teaching and training.
translation_text.mn21:9.1: Once upon a time, mendicants, right here in Sāvatthī there was a housewife named Vedehikā.
translation_text.mn21:9.3: ‘The housewife Vedehikā is gentle, even-tempered, and calm.’
translation_text.mn21:9.4: Now, Vedehikā had a bonded maid named Kāḷī who was deft, tireless, and well-organized in her work.
translation_text.mn21:9.6: ‘My mistress has a good reputation as being
translation_text.mn21:9.8: But does she actually have anger in her and just not show it? Or does she have no anger?
translation_text.mn21:9.9: Or is it just because my work is well-organized that she doesn’t show anger, even though she still has it inside?
translation_text.mn21:9.10: Why don’t I test my mistress?’
translation_text.mn21:9.11: So Kāḷī got up during the day.
translation_text.mn21:9.15: ‘You’re getting up in the day—what’s up with you, wench?’
translation_text.mn21:9.17: ‘Oh, so nothing’s up, you naughty maid, but you get up in the day!’ Angry and upset, she scowled.
translation_text.mn21:9.19: ‘My mistress actually has anger in her and just doesn’t show it; it’s not that she has no anger.
translation_text.mn21:9.20: It’s just because my work is well-organized that she doesn’t show anger, even though she still has it inside.
translation_text.mn21:9.21: Why don’t I test my mistress further?’
translation_text.mn21:9.22: So Kāḷī got up later in the day.
translation_text.mn21:9.26: ‘You’re getting up later in the day—what’s up with you, wench?’
translation_text.mn21:9.28: ‘Oh, so nothing’s up, you naughty maid, but you get up later in the day!’ Angry and upset, she blurted out angry words.
translation_text.mn21:9.30: ‘My mistress actually has anger in her and just doesn’t show it; it’s not that she has no anger.
translation_text.mn21:9.31: It’s just because my work is well-organized that she doesn’t show anger, even though she still has it inside.
translation_text.mn21:9.32: Why don’t I test my mistress further?’
translation_text.mn21:9.33: So Kāḷī got up even later in the day.
translation_text.mn21:9.37: ‘You’re getting up even later in the day—what’s up with you, wench?’
translation_text.mn21:9.39: ‘Oh, so nothing’s up, you naughty maid, but you get up even later in the day!’ Angry and upset, she grabbed a door-pin and hit Kāḷī on the head, cracking it open.
translation_text.mn21:9.40: Then Kāḷī, with blood pouring from her cracked skull, denounced her mistress to the neighbors,
translation_text.mn21:9.41: ‘See, ladies, what the gentle one did!
translation_text.mn21:9.42: See what the even-tempered one did! See what the calm one did!
translation_text.mn21:9.43: How on earth can she grab a door-pin and hit her only maid on the head, cracking it open, just for getting up late?’
translation_text.mn21:9.44: Then after some time the housewife Vedehikā got this bad reputation:
translation_text.mn21:9.45: ‘The housewife Vedehikā is fierce, ill-tempered, and not calm at all.’
translation_text.mn21:10.1: In the same way, a mendicant may be the gentlest of the gentle, the most even-tempered of the even-tempered, the calmest of the calm, so long as they don’t encounter any disagreeable criticism.
translation_text.mn21:10.2: But it’s when they encounter disagreeable criticism that you’ll know whether they’re really gentle, even-tempered, and calm.
translation_text.mn21:10.3: I don’t say that a mendicant is easy to admonish if they make themselves easy to admonish only for the sake of robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.
translation_text.mn21:10.5: Because when they don’t get robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick, they’re no longer easy to admonish.
translation_text.mn21:10.6: But when a mendicant is easy to admonish purely because they honor, respect, revere, worship, and venerate the teaching, then I say that they’re easy to admonish.
translation_text.mn21:10.7: So, mendicants, you should train yourselves: ‘We will be easy to admonish purely because we honor, respect, revere, worship, and venerate the teaching.’
translation_text.mn21:11.1: Mendicants, there are these five ways in which others might criticize you.
translation_text.mn21:11.2: Their speech may be timely or untimely,
translation_text.mn21:11.6: from a heart of love or from secret hate.
translation_text.mn21:11.7: When others criticize you, they may do so in any of these ways.
translation_text.mn21:11.12: If that happens, you should train like this:
translation_text.mn21:11.13: ‘Our minds will not degenerate. We will blurt out no bad words. We will remain full of sympathy, with a heart of love and no secret hate.
translation_text.mn21:11.14: We will meditate spreading a heart of love to that individual. And with them as a basis, we will meditate spreading a heart full of love to everyone in the world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.’
translation_text.mn21:12.1: Suppose a person was to come along carrying a spade and basket
translation_text.mn21:12.3: ‘I shall make this great earth be without earth!’
translation_text.mn21:12.4: And they’d dig all over, scatter all over, spit all over, and urinate all over, saying,
translation_text.mn21:12.7: Could that person make this great earth be without earth?”
translation_text.mn21:12.10: Because this great earth is deep and limitless.
translation_text.mn21:12.11: It’s not easy to make it be without earth.
translation_text.mn21:12.12: That person will eventually get weary and frustrated.”
translation_text.mn21:13.1: “In the same way, there are these five ways in which others might criticize you.
translation_text.mn21:13.2: Their speech may be timely or untimely,
translation_text.mn21:13.6: from a heart of love or from secret hate.
translation_text.mn21:13.7: When others criticize you, they may do so in any of these ways.
translation_text.mn21:13.12: If that happens, you should train like this:
translation_text.mn21:13.13: ‘Our minds will not degenerate. We will blurt out no bad words. We will remain full of sympathy, with a heart of love and no secret hate.
translation_text.mn21:13.14: We will meditate spreading a heart of love to that individual. And with them as a basis, we will meditate spreading a heart like the earth to everyone in the world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.’
translation_text.mn21:14.1: Suppose a person was to come along with dye such as red lac, turmeric, indigo, or rose madder,
translation_text.mn21:14.3: ‘I shall draw pictures in space, making pictures appear there.’
translation_text.mn21:14.5: Could that person draw pictures in space?”
translation_text.mn21:14.8: Because space has no form or appearance.
translation_text.mn21:14.9: It’s not easy to draw pictures there.
translation_text.mn21:14.10: That person will eventually get weary and frustrated.”
translation_text.mn21:15.1: “In the same way, if others criticize you in any of these five ways … you should train like this:
translation_text.mn21:15.2: ‘… We will meditate spreading a heart of love to that person. And with them as a basis, we will meditate spreading a heart like space to everyone in the world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.’
translation_text.mn21:16.1: Suppose a person was to come along carrying a blazing grass torch,
translation_text.mn21:16.3: ‘I shall burn and scorch the river Ganges with this blazing grass torch.’
translation_text.mn21:16.5: Could that person burn and scorch the river Ganges with a blazing grass torch?”
translation_text.mn21:16.8: Because the river Ganges is deep and limitless.
translation_text.mn21:16.9: It’s not easy to burn and scorch it with a blazing grass torch.
translation_text.mn21:16.10: That person will eventually get weary and frustrated.”
translation_text.mn21:17.1: “In the same way, if others criticize you in any of these five ways … you should train like this:
translation_text.mn21:17.2: ‘… We will meditate spreading a heart of love to that individual. And with them as a basis, we will meditate spreading a heart like the Ganges to everyone in the world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.’
translation_text.mn21:18.1: Suppose there was a catskin bag that was rubbed, well-rubbed, very well-rubbed, soft, silky, rid of rustling and crackling.
translation_text.mn21:18.2: Then a person comes along carrying a stick or a stone,
translation_text.mn21:18.4: ‘I shall make this soft catskin bag rustle and crackle with this stick or stone.’
translation_text.mn21:18.6: Could that person make that soft catskin bag rustle and crackle with that stick or stone?”
translation_text.mn21:18.9: Because that catskin bag is rubbed, well-rubbed, very well-rubbed, soft, silky, rid of rustling and crackling.
translation_text.mn21:18.10: It’s not easy to make it rustle or crackle with a stick or stone.
translation_text.mn21:18.11: That person will eventually get weary and frustrated.”
translation_text.mn21:19.1: “In the same way, there are these five ways in which others might criticize you.
translation_text.mn21:19.2: Their speech may be timely or untimely,
translation_text.mn21:19.6: from a heart of love or from secret hate.
translation_text.mn21:19.7: When others criticize you, they may do so in any of these ways.
translation_text.mn21:19.12: If that happens, you should train like this:
translation_text.mn21:19.13: ‘Our minds will not degenerate. We will blurt out no bad words. We will remain full of sympathy, with a heart of love and no secret hate.
translation_text.mn21:19.14: We will meditate spreading a heart of love to that individual. And with them as a basis, we will meditate spreading a heart like a catskin bag to everyone in the world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.’
translation_text.mn21:20.1: Even if low-down bandits were to sever you limb from limb with a two-handed saw, anyone who had a malevolent thought on that account would not be following my instructions.
translation_text.mn21:20.2: If that happens, you should train like this:
translation_text.mn21:20.3: ‘Our minds will not degenerate. We will blurt out no bad words. We will remain full of sympathy, with a heart of love and no secret hate.
translation_text.mn21:20.4: We will meditate spreading a heart of love to that individual. And with them as a basis, we will meditate spreading a heart full of love to everyone in the world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.’
translation_text.mn21:21.1: If you frequently reflect on this advice on the simile of the saw,
translation_text.mn21:21.2: do you see any criticism, large or small, that you could not endure?”
translation_text.mn21:21.4: “So, mendicants, you should frequently reflect on this advice on the simile of the saw.
translation_text.mn21:21.5: This will be for your lasting welfare and happiness.”
translation_text.mn21:21.6: That is what the Buddha said.
translation_text.mn21:21.7: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.
